title: Correlative Characterisation of Neutron-Irradiation Damage Induced in Zr Alloys
content: Zr alloys have been widely used as cladding materials in fission reactors for decades, the most important reason is the low neutron cross section, which means the thermal neutrons released during fission reactions are not absorbed [1-3]. However, the formation of atomic- to micro-scale irradiation damage like vacancies, solute clusters, dislocations are still unavoidable. These can cause solute redistribution and volume expansion, undermining mechanical properties and causing serious safety issues. Therefore, understanding how the metallic matrix reacts to neutron irradiation and how to improve the structural stability is vital for continued development of nuclear energy. Atom probe tomography (APT) is very suitable to characterise these defects at near atomic-scale spatial resolution with ppm-level chemical sensitivity.
